title: Sara Z‚Äôs Hou-SikBaking Project
text:
My name is Sara Zong. ‚ÄúHou-Sik‚Äù is delicious in Cantonese, my mother tongue.
I love the combination of a coffee/tea and some sweet bake goods, just imagine a cup of pour-over coffee with a freshly out-of-the-oven vanilla souffle üòã.
Bake goods are usually so much better when they just come out of the oven. In addition, I like my treats to be less sugary than what I could buy a lot of the times so that I could better taste the flavor of the ingredients.
From years of working in the laboratory on molecular biology, not only I developed the skills to make precise measurements and follow standard operating procedure easily, but also the habit to understand the purposes of the steps. I enjoy tweaking the process to make it more efficient or to customize the outputs.
Thus, I decided to start my hou-sik baking project. Learning to bake the sweets I love, and to enjoy fresh bake goods with a cup of coffee/tea. Well, I have to admit, there are the influences from The Great British Bake Off and Bake Off: The Professionals. Those bakers in the shows are my inspirations üí°.

title: Sara Z‚Äôs Favorite Dessert Recipes

title: Vanilla Souffle with Lemon Curd
text:
Ingredients

Vanilla Souffles (amount: four 8oz ramekins)Lemon Curd (amount: ~120 ml)








  
    
       
      Quantity
    
  
  
    1. large eggs (50g each without shell)
4
    2. sugar for egg yolk
15 g
    3. vanilla extract
15 ml1
    4. cake flour
25 g2
    5. milk
200 ml
    6. unsalted butter
35 g
    7. sugar for egg white
40 g3
    8. powder sugar
1 Tbsp
  
  
  
    
      1 Original recipe uses 4g of vanilla bean paste and it's equivalent to 1 Tbsp of vanilla extract according to websearch.
    
    
      2 Can use 3g corn starch plus 22g all purpose flour as the cake flour substitute.
    
    
      3 Original recipe uses 55g of sugar for egg white, reduce to 40g since enjoying the souffle with some lemon curd.
    
  












  
    
       
      Quantity1
    
  
  
    1. large eggs (50g each without shell)
1
    2. lemon zest
1 lemon
    3. lemon juice (freshly squeezed)
40 g
    4. butter (unsalted/lightly salted)
18 g
    5. sugar
28 g
    6. sea salt (fine)
1/24 tsp
  
  
  
    
      1 Original recipe uses 6 eggs, 6-8 lemons, 240g lemon juice, 113g unsalted butter, 200g sugar, and 1/4 tsp fine sea salt.

title: Vanilla Souffle with Lemon Curd
text:
High-level How To

SouffleLemon Curd



Grease ramekins with butter and coat with sugar.
Whisk the egg yolks with the sugar.
Sift in the flour to step 2, mix well.
Warm up the milk and butter to ~40C and pour in 20 ml to step 3, mix well.
Add the rest of the milk, cook on low heat and mix constantly until thicken to paste.
Transfer to a bowl, add the vanilla extract, mix well.
Cover the custard with a plastic wrap and cool to room temperature.
Whisk the egg white with a hand mixer and add sugar 1/3 at a time, until soft peaks.
Fold in the meringue to the custard 1/3 at a time with a whisk and a spatula.
Divide the batter among the ramekins.
Bake at 400F for about 15mins until the top is brown.
Dust with powdered sugar immediately after taking out.




Rub sugar and lemon zest together in a pot until like wet sand.
Add lemon juice to step 1.
Whisk egg with salt, add to step 2, and mix well.
Cook on low heat, and mix constantly until the mix thicken to sauce.
Sift mix to butter.

title: Vanilla Souffle with Lemon Curd
text:
Sara Z‚Äôs Notes/Tips:
Vanilla souffle:

To coat the ramekins with butter and sugar, first melt a small amount of butter in a microwave or in some hot water. Brush the butter onto the ramekin with upward strokes to help the souffle batter rise vertically when bake. Put a table spoon of granulated sugar in the ramekin and rotate it until its inside is fully coated with sugar. Coating the side of the ramekin with sugar provides surface for the souffle batter to rise.
When cooking the flour-milk mix in step 5 into paste, make sure to constantly stir the mix on low heat to ensure even cooking and prevent burn. Turn off the stove when the mix has similar consistency as the soft peak meringue. Transfer the mix into a bowl to prevent further cooking in the hot pot.

Lemon curd:

Zest the lemon(s), but don‚Äôt cut too deep to avoid the pith, which is the white, spongy part of the lemon peel that could taste bitter.

title: Vanilla Souffle with Lemon Curd

Lemon curd recipe is from The Best Lemon Curd

title: Chocolate Souffle
text:
Step by Step

Grease ramekins with butter and coat with sugar.
Melt chocolate and butter over simmering water.
Add egg yolks and salt to warm mixture in step 2.
Whisk the egg white with a hand mixer and add sugar in 1/3 at a time.
Whip the mixture in step 3 with a hand mixer.
Fold in the meringue 1/3 at a time with a spatula.
Divide the batter among the ramekins.
Bake at 400F for about 15mins
Dust with powdered sugar immediately after taking out.

title: Chocolate Souffle
text:
SZzZz‚Äôs Notes:

Brushing butter onto the ramekin with upward stroke and coating the side with sugar provide surface for the souffle mix to rise.
Recipe #1 is pretty much enough to fill four 8oz ramekins.
Since serving this with lemon curd, reduce the sugar in the souffle.

    Filling for 4 tarts

title: Puff Pastry Egg Tart
text:
Step by Step

Part 1: oil dough

Leave butter to warm up at room temperature.
Mix 375g of flour with 500g of butter with a hand mixer, start slow and increase speed to make sure mixing well.
Lay a piece of parchment paper on a rectangular container, shape the dough evenly in the container with a spatula/dough cutter.
Chill dough in freezer for >= 15 mins.



Part 2: water dough

Put 375g flour, 75g room temperature butter, 25g of sugar, and 1 egg together, mix with hand mixer on slow.
Till ingredients in 5 mixed pretty well, increase mixing speed to medium and slowly add water to the dough incrementally, 10mL at a time. Stop when consistency of the dough is similar to the dough in part 1.
Put plenty of flour on work bench, knead dough from part 2 lightly and let dough rest for >= 10 minutes.
Roll dough to the size of the dough in part1, cover dough in part 1 and leave dough in freezer until hard (>= 2 hours!?).



Part 3: pastry folding

Take the dough out of freezer and leave at room temperature to warm up, ~15 minutes. Check every 5 to 10 minutes to determine the exact amount of time needed.
Put plenty of flour on the work bench, with the oil dough on top and water dough at the bottom, evenly and gently beat and roll the dough in different directions: horizontally, vertically, and diagonally.
Flip the dough to make sure the dough is rolled out evenly into a rectangular shape.
With the long edge toward you, fold the shorter edges toward the center to the dough is 1/3 of the rolled out size.
Repeat 10, 11, and 12. Make sure to brush away excessive amount of flour stuck to the dough.
Repeat 10, 11, and 12 one more time and fold the dough to 1/4 of the rolled out size instead of 1/4 this time.
Freeze the dough until it‚Äôs hard (>= 2 hours!?)
Take the dough out of the freezer and warm up at room temperature, ~ 15 minutes. Roll the dough out evenly into a 0.3 to 0.4mm sheet, use the fluted cutter to cut out the tart crusts.
Freeze the crusts till they are hard.



Part 4: filling

Thaw crusts to room temperature, insert one into a mold, gentely press down in the center and turn the mold while continue pressing in spiral motion toward the rim of the mold. Make sure the crust go over the rim of the mold. Put crust back in fridge while preparing for the filling.
Dissolve sugar in hot water and let it cool to room temperature.
Beat egg, add evaporated milk and sugar water, seive filling to ensure smooth filling after bake.

title: Puff Pastry Egg Tart
text:
SZzZz‚Äôs Notes:

Experiment on 7/9/2025:

Used 1/5 amount of the dough ingredients, enough to make about 10 tarts

Kirkland organic flour and corn starch (25%)
KerryGold salted butter

Used ~20mL of water instead of 10mL to make the water dough, seemed to need even more water.
When folding the dough, the dough initially thawed slow, but the oil dough became pasty fast.


‚Ä¶ (failed experiments in between) ‚Ä¶

Experiment on 8/10/2025:

Used 2/5 amount of the dough
Used ~60mL of water to make the water dough
LEARNED:

Important to warm the dough to room temperature before baking, else the dough will not be fully cooked.
When knead the crust into the mold, start at the bottom and press hard enough that the dough
